She should in ground vnsanctified bin lodg'd
Till the last trumpet: for charitable prayers,
Flints and peebles should be throwne on her:
Yet here she is allow'd her virgin Crants,
Her mayden strewments, and the bringing home
Of bell and buriall.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Must there no more be doone?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: No more be doone.
We should prophane the seruice of the dead,
To sing a Requiem and such rest to her
As to peace‐parted soules.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Lay her i'th earth,
And from her faire and vnpolluted flesh
May Violets spring: I tell thee churlish Priest,
A ministring Angell shall my sister be
When thou lyest howling.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What, the faire Ophelia.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Sweets to the sweet, farewell,
I hop't thou should'd haue bin my Hamlets wife,
I thought thy bride‐bed to haue deckt sweet mayd,
And not haue strew'd thy graue.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: O trebble woe
Fall ten times double on that cursed head,
Whose wicked deed thy most ingenious sence
Depriued thee of, hold off the earth a while,
Til I haue caught her once more in mine armes;
Now pile your dust vpon the quick and dead,
Till of this flat a mountaine you haue made
To retop old Pelion, or the skyesh head
Of blew Olympus.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What is he whose griefe
Beares such an Emphasis, whose phrase of sorrow
Coniures the wandring Stars, and makes them stand
Like wonder wounded hearers? tis I
Hamlet the Dane.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: The Diuell take thy soule,

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l:
Thou pray'st not well, I prethee take thy fingers
(from my throat,
For though I am not spleenatiue rash,
Yet haue I in me something dangerous,
Which let thy wisdome feare; hold off thy hand?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Pluck them asunder,

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Hamlet, Hamlet.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Good my Lord be quiet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why I will fight with him vpon this theame
Vntill my eye‐lids will no longer wagge.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: O my sonne, what theame?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I lou'd Ophelia: forty thousand brothers
Could not with all their quantity of loue
Make vp my sum. What wilt thou doo for her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O he is mad Laertes.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: For loue of God forbeare him?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: S'wounds shew me what th'out doo:

Woo't weep, woo't fight, woo't fast, woo't teare thy
(selfe,
Woo't drinke vp Esill, eat a Crocadile
I'le doo't: doost come here to whine?
To out‐face me with leaping in her graue,
Be buried quick with her, and so will I.
And if thou prate of mountaines, let them throw
Millions of Acres on vs, till our ground
Sindging his pate against the burning Zone
Make Ossa like a wart, nay and thou'lt mouth,
I'le rant as well as thou.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: This is meere madnesse,
And this a while the fit will worke on him,
Anon as patient as a female Doe
When that her golden cuplets are disclosed
His silence will sit drooping.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Heare you sir,
What is the reason that you vse me thus?
I lou'd you euer, but it is no matter,
Let Hercules himselfe do what he may

The Cat will mew, a Dog will haue his dayExit Hamlet,
and Horatio.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I pray thee good Horatio wait vpon him.
Strengthen your patience in our last nights speech,
Weele put the matter to the present push:
Good Gertrard set some watch ouer your sonne,
This graue shall haue a liuing monument,
An houre of quiet thereby shall we see
Tell then in patience our proceeding be.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: So much for this sir, now shal you see the other,
You do remember all the circumstance.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Remember it my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Sir in my heart there was a kind of fighting
That would not let me sleep, me thouht I lay
Worse then the mutines in the bilbo's, rashly,
And praisd be rashnes for it: let v know,
Our indiscretion sometimes serues vs well
When our deep plots do fal, and that should learne vs
There's a diuinity that shapes our ends,
Rough hew them how we will.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: That is most certaine.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Vp from my Cabin,
My sea‐gowne scarft about me in the darke
Gropt I to find out them, had my desire,
Fingard their packet, and in fine withdrew
To mine owne roome againe making, so bold.
My feares forgetting manners to vnfold
Their grand commission; where I found Horatio
A royall knauery, an exact command
Larded with many seuerall sorts of reasons,
Importing Denmarks health, and Englands to,
With hoe such Bugs and Goblins in my life,
That on the superuise no leisure bated,
No not to stay the grinding of the Axe,
My head should be strooke off.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I'st possible?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Here's the commission, read it at more leisure,
But wilt thou heare now how I did proceed.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Being thus be‐netted round with villaines,
Or I could make a Prologue to my braines,
They had begun the Play, I sat me downe,
Deuis'd a new commission, wrote it faire,
I once did hold it as our Statists doe
A basenesse to write faire, and labourd much
How to forget that learning, but sir now
It did me yeomans seruice, wilt thou know
Th' effect of what I wrote?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: An earnest coniuration from the King,
As England was his faithfull Tributarie,
As loue between them like the Palme might florish,
As peace should still her wheaten Garland weare
And stand a Comma tweene their amities,
And many such like, as sir of great charge,
That on the view, and knowing of these contens,
Without debatement further more or lesse
He should those bearers put to sudden death,
Not shriuing time allow'd.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: How was this seald?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why euen in that was Heauen ordinant,
I had my fathers signet in my purse
Which was the modell of that Danish seale,
Folded the writ vp in the forme of th'other,
Subscrib'd it, gau't th' impression, plac'd it safely,
The changling neuer knowne: now the next day
Was our Sea‐fight, and what to this was sequent
Thou knowest already,

sp.speaker: Hora,
sp.l: So Guyldensterne and Rosencraus go too't.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: They are not neer my conscience; their defeat
Does by their owne insinuation grow,
Tis dangerous when the baser nature comes
Betweene the passe and fell incensed points
Of mightie Opposites.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Why what a King is this!

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Does it not think thee stand me now vpon?
He that hath kild my King, and whor'd my mother,
Pop't in betweene the election and my hopes,
Throwne out his Angle for my proper life,
And with such cosnage, i'st not perfect conscience?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Your Lordship is right welcome backe to Denmarke.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I humbly thanke you sir.
Doo'st know this Water‐flie?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: No my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Thy state is the more gracious, for tis a vice to know
him, He hath much land and fertill: let a beast be Lord of beasts,
and his Crib shall stand at the Kings messe, tis a chough, but as I
say, spacious in the possession of durt.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l:
Sweet Lord, if your Lordship were at leisure, I should
impart a thing to you from his Maiesty.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
I will receiue it sir with all diligence of spirit, your bon­
net to his right vse, tis for the head.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I thanke your Lordship, it is very hot.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No beleeue me, tis very cold, the wind is Northerly.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: It is indifferent cold my Lord indeed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
But yet me thinks it is very soultry and hot, or my com­
plexion.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l:
Exceedingly my Lord, it is very soultry as t'were I can­
not tell how: my Lord his Maiesty bad me signifie to you, that a
has layed a great wager on your head, sir this is the matter.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I beseech you remember.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p:
Nay good my Lord for my ease in good faith, sir here is
newly come to Court Laertes, beleeue mee an absolute Gentle­ man,
Prince of Denmarke. man, full of most excellent differences, of very soft societie,
and great showing: indeed to speake feelingly of him, he is the
Card or Kalender of Gentrie: for you shall find in him the conti­
nent of what part a Gentleman would see.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Sir, his definement suffers no perdition in you, though I
know to diuide him inuentorially, would dizzie th'arithmetick
of memorie, and yet but raw neither, in respect of his quick saile,
but in the verity of extolment, I take him to be a soule of great ar­
ticle, and his infusion of such dearth and rarenesse, as to make true
dixion of him, his semblable is his mirrour, and who els would
trace him, his vmbrage, nothing more.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Your Lordship speakes most infallibly of him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
The concernancy sir, why do we wrap the Gentleman in
our mor rawer breath?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l:
Ist not possible to vnderstand in another tongue, you will
doo't sir really.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What imports the nomination of this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Of Laertes.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: His purse is empty already, all's golden words are spent.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Of him sir.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I know you are not ignorant.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
I would you did sir, yet in faith if you did, it would, not
much approue me, well sir.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: You are ignorant of what excellence Laertes is.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
I dare not confesse that, least I should compare with him
in excellence, but to know a man well, were to know himselfe.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l:
I meane sir for this weapon, but in the imputation laid
on him by them in his meed, he's vnfellowed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What's his weapon?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Rapiar and Dagger.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: That's two of his weapons, but well.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p:
The King sir hath wagerd with him six Barbary horses
against the which he has impaund as I take it six French Rapiers
and Poinards, with their assignes, as girdle, hanger and so. Three
of the carriages in faith, are very deare to fancie, very responsiue
to the hilts, most delicate carriages, and of very liberall conceit.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What call you the carriages?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l:
I knew you must be edified by the margent ere you had
done.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: The carriage sir are the hangers.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
The phrase would be more German to the matter if we
could carrie a Canon by our sides, I would it might bee hangers
till then, but on, six Barbary horses against six French Swords their
assignes, and three liberall conceited carriages, that's the French
bet against the Danish, why is this all you call it?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p:
The King sir, hath laid sir, that in a dozen passes betweene
your selfe and him, he shall not exceed you three hits, he hath laid
on twelue for nine, and it would eome to immediate triall, if your
Lordship would vouchsafe the answere.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How if I answere no?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I meane my Lord the opposition of your person in trial.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Sir I will walke heere in the hall, If it please his Maiesty,
it is the breathing time of day with me, let the foiles be brought,
the Gentleman willing, and the King hold his purpose; I will win
for him and I can, if not I will gaine nothing but my shame, and
the odde hits.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: Shall I deliuer you so?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: To this effect sir, after what florish your nature will.

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.l: I commend my dutie to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
Yours doo's well to commend it himselfe, there are no
tongues else for his turne.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: This Lapwing runs away with the shell on his head.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
A dd so sir with his dugge before a suckt it, thus has he
and many more of the same breed that I know the drossie age
dotes on, onely got the tune of the time, and out of an habit of
incounter, a kind of mistie collecton, which carries them through
and through the most profane and trennowned opinons, and doe
but blow them to their triall, the bubbles are out.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
My Lord, his Maiestie commended him to you by yong
Ostricke, who brings back to him that you attend him in the hall,
he sends to know if your pleasure hold to play with Laertes, or that
you will take longer time?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
I am constant to my purposes, they follow the Kings
pleasure, if his fitnesse speakes, mine is ready: now or whensoeuer,
prouided I be so able as now.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The King and Queene and all are comming downe.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: In happy time.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l:
The Queene desires you to vse some gentle entertain­
ment to Laertes, before you go to play.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Shee well instructs me.

sp.speaker: Hora,
sp.l: You will loose my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
I do not think so, since he went into France, I haue bin
in continuall practise, I shall winne at the oddes; thou would'st
not thinke how ill all's heere about my heart, but it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Nay good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
It is but foolerie, but it is such a kind of game‐giuing,
as would perhaps trouble a woman.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l:
If your mind dislike any thing, obay it. I shall forestall
their repaire hither and say you are not fit.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.p:
Not a whit we defie Augurie, there is speciall prouidence
in the fall of a Sparrow, if it bee, tis not to come, if it bee not to
come, it will be now, if it be not now, yet it will come, the readi­
nesse is all, since no man of ought he leaues, knowes what ist to
leaue betimes, let be.

div2.stage:
A table prepared, Trumpets, Drums and Officers with Cushions,
King, Queene, and all the state, Foiles, Daggers, and Laertes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come Hamlet, come and take this hand from me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Giue me your pardon sir, I haue done you wrong,
But pardon't as you are a Genleman, this presence knowes,
And you must needs haue heard, how I am punisht
With a sore distraction: what I haue done
That might your nature, honour, and exception
Roughly awake I heere proclaime was madnesse,
Wast Hamlet wronged Laertes? neuer Hamlet,
If Hamlet from himselfe be tane away,
And when he's not himselfe, doe's wrong Laertes,
Then Hamlet doe's it not, Hamlet denies it,
Who does it then? his madnesse. Ift be so,
Hamlet is of the faction that is wronged,
His madnesse is poore Hamlets enemie,
Let my disclaiming from a purpos'd euill,
Free me so farre in your most generous thoughts
That Ihaue shot my Arrow ore the house
And hurt my brother.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I am satisfied in nature,
Whose motiue in this case should stirre me most
To my reuenge, but in my tearmes of honor
I ftand aloofe, and will no reconcilement,
Till by some elder Masters of knowne honour
I haue a voice and president of peace
To my name vngor'd: but all that time
I doe receiue your offered loue, like loue,
And will not wrong it.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l:
I imbrace it freely, and will this brothers wager
frankly play.
Giue vs the Foiles.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Come, one for me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Ile be your foile Laertes, in mine ignorance
Your skill shall like a starre i'th darkest night
Stick fiery of indeed.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: You mock me sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No by this hand.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l:
Giue them the foiles yong Ostrick, cosin Ham.
You know the wager.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Very well my Lord.
Your Grace has laid the oddes a'th weaker side.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I doe not feare it, I haue seene you both,
But since he is better, we haue therefore oddes.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: This is to heauy: let me see another.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: This likes me well, these foiles haue all a length.

sp.speaker: Ostr.
sp.l: I my good Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Set me the stoops of wine vpon the table,
If Hamlet giue the first or second hit,
Or quit in answer of the third exchange,
Let all the battlements their Ordnance fire.
The King shall drinke to Hamlets better breath,
And in the cup an Onix shall he throw,
Richer then that which foure sucessiue Kings
In Denmarkes Crowne haue worne: giue me the cups,
And let the Kettle to the Trumpet speake,
The Trumpet to the Cannoneere without,
The Canons to the Heauens, the Heauens to Earth,

Now the King drinkes to Hamlet, come begin.Trumpets
the while.
And you the Iudges beare a warie eye.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Come on sir.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Come my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: One.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Iudgement.

sp.speaker: Ostr.
sp.l:
A hit, a very palpable hit.Drum, Trumpets and shot.
Flourish, a Peece goes off.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Well, againe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stay, giue me drink, Hamlet this Pearle is thine.
Heere's to thy health, giue him the cup.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Ile play this bout first, set it by a while
Come, another hit. What say you?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: I doe confest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Our sonne shall winne.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: He's fat and scant of breath.
Heere Hamlet take my napkin rub thy browes,
The Queene carowses to thy fortune Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Good Madam.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Gertrard, doe not drinke.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I will my Lord, I pray you pardon me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It is the poysned cup, it is too late.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I dare not drinke yet Madam, by and by.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Come, let me wipe thy face.

sp.speaker: Laer,
sp.l: My Lord, Ile hit him now.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I doe not think't.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: And yet it is almost againft my conscience,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Come for the third Laertes, you doe but dally,
I pray you passe with your best violence
I am sure you make a wanton of me

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Say you so come on.

sp.speaker: Ostr.
sp.l: Nothing neither way.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Haue at you now.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Part them, they are incenst.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay come againe.

sp.speaker: Ostr.
sp.l: Looke to the Queene there hoe.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: They bleed on both sides, how is it my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ostr.
sp.l: How ist Laertes?

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: Why as a Woodcock to mine owne fpringe. Ostrick
I am iustly kild with mine owne treachery.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How does the Queene?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: She sounds to see them bleed.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: No, no, the drink, the drink, O my deare Ham,
The drink, the drink, I am poysned.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O villaine! hoe let the dore be lock't,
Treachery, seek it out.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l: It is here Hamlet thou art slaine,
No medecine in the world can do thee good,
In thee there is not halfe an houres life,
The treacherous instrument is in my hand
Vnbated and enuenom'd, the foule practise
Hath turn'd it selfe on me, loe here I lye
Neuer to rise againe: thy mother's poysned,
I am no more, the King, the Kings too blame.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: The point enuenom'd to, then venom to thy work

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Treason, treason.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O yet defend me friends, I am but hurt.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Here thou incestious damned Dane,
Drink of this potion, is the Onixe here?
Follow my mother.

sp.speaker: Laer.
sp.l:
He is iustly serued, it is a poison temperd by him­
(selfe
Exchange forgiuenesse with me noble Hamlet,
Mine and my fathers death come not vpon thee,
Nor thine on me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Heauen make thee free of it, I follow thee;
I am dead Horatio, wretched Queene adiew.
You that looke pale and tremble at this chance,
That are but mutes, or audience to this act,
Had I but time as this fell Sergeant Death
Is strict in his arrest. O I could tell you!
But let it be; Horatio I am dead,
Thou liuest, report me and my cause aright
To the vnsatisfied.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Neuer beleeue it;
I am more an antike Roman then a Dane,
Heer's yet some liquor left.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: As th'art a man
Giue me the cup, let goe, by heauen I'le hate,
O God Horatio! what a wounded name
Things standing thus vnknowne, shall I leaue behind me?
If thou didst euer hold me in thy heart,
Absent thee from felicity a while,

And in this harsh world draw thy breath in paineA march a
farre off.
To tell my story: what warlike noise is this?

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Young Fortinbrasse with conquest come from Poland,
Th'Embassadors of England giues this warlike volly.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O I die Horatio,
The potent poyson quite ore‐growes my spirit,
I cannot liue to heare the newes from England,
But I do prophesie the election lights
On Fortinbrasse, he has my dying voyce,
So tell him with th'occurrants more and lesse
Which haue solicited, the reft is silence.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l:
Now cracks a noble heart, good night sweet
(Prince,
And flight of Angels singe thee to thy rest.
Why dooes the drum come hether?

sp.speaker: Fortin.
sp.l: Where is this sight?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: VVhat is it you would see?
If ought of woe, or wonder, cease your search.

sp.speaker: Fortin.
sp.l: This quarry cries on hauock, O proud death
What feast is toward in thine eternall cell,
That thou so many Princes at a shot
So bloudily hast strooke?

sp.speaker: Embas.
sp.l: The sight is dismall
And our affaires from England come too late,
The eares are sencelesse that should giue vs hearing,
To tell him his commandement is fulfill'd,
That Rosencraus and Guyldensterne are dead,
Where should we haue our thanks?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Not from his mouth
Had it th'ability of life to thanke you;
e neuer gaue commandement for their death;
But since so iump vpon this bloody question
You from the Pollock warres, and you from England
Are here arriued, giue order that these bodies
High on a stage be placed so the view,
And let me speak, to th'yet vnknowing world
How these things came about; so shall you heare
Of cruell, bloody and vnnaturall acts.
Of accidentall iudgements, casuall slaughters,
Of deaths put on by cunning, and for no cause,
And in this vpshot, purposes miftooke,
Falne on the Inuenters heads: all this can I
Truely deliuer.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Let vs hast to heare it,
And call the noblest to the audience,
For me with sorrow I embrace my fortune,
I haue some rights of memory in this Kingdome,
Which now to cleime my vantage doth inuite me.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Of that I shall haue also cause to speake,
And from his mouth, whose voice wil draw no more,
But let this same be presently perform'd

Euen while mens mindes are wilde, least more mis­
(chance
On plots and errors happen.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Let foure Captaines
Beare Hamlet like a Souldier to the stage,
For he was likely, had he been put on,
To haue proued moft royall; and for his passage,
The Souldiers musick and the right of warre
Speake loudly for him:
Take vp the bodies, such a sight as this,
Becomes the field, but here showes much amisse.

Goe bid the Souldiers shoot.Exeunt.
Perfect
Quaritch
F.S. Ferguson
6.5. 1907 STC
